title: The Treasure Deck · SING 9 Wild Card Treasures
description: The treasure deck is managed by the DJ at the DJ station. Treasures are wild card elements that can be inserted into any SING 9 experience node at any moment to enrich, surprise, gear-shift, or reward. They are not the main story — they are the bass drum. Boom. Boom. Boom. They keep the beat going. They keep the audience from falling asleep. They are the spice in the story's kitchen.
rule: Treasures are always: connection-based, respect-based, and earned. None of the bad ones — we know which ones those are. All of the good ones — we know which ones those are too.
deployment: The DJ deploys a treasure when: (1) the story needs a gear shift, (2) the pacing needs a wild card injection, (3) a reward has been earned by the story arc, or (4) the Wild Card Observer has appeared and the treasure follows his appearance.

examples: The summer adventure in Kachemak Bay
Fishing with Captain Lance at 4am

The campfire on the spit with the mountains behind
categories.deployment_beat: Use when the story needs a complete gear shift to raw nature and genuine humans. Alaska resets everything. Drop it like a key change in a song — the viewer lands somewhere completely different and knows it immediately.
categories.score: 01 - THE MAGICAL CARIBBEAN HAT'S ALASKA SUMMER ADVENTURE (playlist-4) — the only track explicitly for this treasure. Then campfire melody. Then morning in paradise.
categories.ino_piro_dynamic: Piro cannot follow Ino to Alaska. The Eagles up in the trees would eat the cat. Alaska is Ino's world entirely.

categories.category: Wild Card Observer · The Mysterious Watcher
categories.description: The Wild Card Observer is technically both a treasure AND a trading card. He is the gentle signal that something important just happened. Glasses. A hat. Unknown identity — deliberately unknown. Shows up at key moments. Never speaks. Just seen. Then gone. The post-singularity 'APPLAUSE' sign.
examples: He's at the bar at the moment the deal closes
He's in the background when the boat arrives
He's standing at the edge of the crowd when the Fanny turns
He watches from a distance when the cat goes back inside
categories.deployment_beat: Use exactly when the story reaches a moment of genuine significance that the story itself is not announcing. The observer is the story's way of winking at the attentive viewer: you just saw something. The inattentive viewer won't notice him. That's the point.
categories.score: Nothing. Silence. Or the observer's own motif — a single, unrepeated chord that belongs only to him. After he appears: whatever score belongs to what just happened.
categories.ino_piro_dynamic: The observer watches both. He is not aligned. He is documentation. He is the universe taking note.

deployment_rules.timing: The DJ deploys a treasure when the story needs it — not when the EP wants to show it off. The treasure serves the story. The story does not exist to host the treasure.
deployment_rules.frequency: Never deploy more than 2 treasures in a single 30-minute segment. The treasure is rare because scarcity is what makes it feel like a treasure.
deployment_rules.sequencing: The treasure follows a story beat, it does not replace one. Deploy after the emotion is established, not before.
deployment_rules.the_bass_drum: The treasure deck is the bass drum. Boom. Boom. Boom. It keeps the beat going. It keeps the audience awake and eager. It is never the melody — always the rhythm underneath.
